data.title: Completions not shown if the string they overlap appears again in the completion text.
Node launch 'program' parsed incorrectly
data.body:
I'm trying to launch Mocha tests in debug mode with TypeScript and ts-node, this should work (and used to work I believe):

```
{
    "type": "node",
    "request": "launch",
    "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/_mocha",
    ...
}
```

but I'm getting:

```
Cannot launch program 'c:\Temp\vscode-ts-node-debugging\node_modules\.bin_mocha'; setting the 'outDir or outFiles' attribute might help.
```

Note that there is a backslash missing in that message (`\.bin_mocha` should be `\.bin\_mocha`) so that leads me to think that the `program` value is parsed incorrectly. If I change my `launch.json` to contain:

```
"program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/mocha/bin/_mocha"
```

all works fine (but it's more correct and most tutorials use `node_modules/.bin/_mocha`).

- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:09.760Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063

data.title: Allow escape to be used to close terminal
data.body:
Fixes #33683

A `keydown` listener is added to detect the escape key being pressed as `keypress` will not detect the escape key.

Checks for the escape key in the listener so modifier keys will not be detected.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1

Thanks, VsCode team for the awesome 1.16.1 Update... but I think there is more room for improvement,
If there is an option to save the workspace will be useful... I use 2 integrated terminals for my work. I  have to start it manually each time it gets back to work. if there is an option to save these all as a project it would be easier and fun to work. data.title: Please rid of the () "" {} autocomplete nonesence
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-autohotkey|sle|0.2.1

Hit " or ( or { and a second matching " ) }  appears. and often, if not used from the start, like adding a terminating " on a string... a superfluous " appears or sometimes it double quote some text because I hit " where there was something there already. Sometimes delete the extra quote and the other one is deleted too! Frankly this is annoying, I find myself typing " and deleting the extra and retyping the quote I wanted because it's now gone!!!, And how about compile errors due to added or removed matching quotes?. How is constantly fighting the compile errors due to poorly placed matching ) " } worth my time! It's not saving any time, It's not like I can't double tap " myself or shift tap {} in 1 millisecond... something we've all done for years now. This Auto Typing the matching pair is just silly and goes against every programming fiber in my body!! I don't need a ghost adding characters to my code behind my back

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use the product all day and curse every time you type " or ( or { and it anoyed you or broke your code behind your back that's the steps to reproduce


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Feature Request - Async validation for ShowInputBox
data.body:
Scenario:

The [Azure App Service Extension](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-azureappservice) uses ShowInputBox to prompt user for the name of the new web app to be created. Then it checks the name availability by trying to resolve the DNS name of the web app. This operation can take up to a few seconds depending on network speed.

Currently the ShowInputBox doesn't seem to support async validation function, which means we can only validate after ShowInputBox function is done and re-prompt if the DNS value turns out not available.

The optimum experience: ShowInputBox supports async validation, when the validation function is running, the input box shows a progress indicator and won't allow the value be accepted (pressing Enter won't close the box), ESC should still cancel the input regardless.

data.title: Delete-all-left command does not continue to delete previous lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 (macOS 10.12.6)
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vsc-material-theme|Equ|1.0.2
TabOut|alb|0.1.4
better-whitespace|chm|1.0.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1
subtle-brackets|raf|2.0.2
scope-info|sie|0.2.0

(5 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file with multiple lines
2. Place the cursor in any line that's not the first line
3. Use the "Delete All Left" command/keybinding to delete all characters to the left
4. Repeat the keybinding or command -- nothing happens.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The standard OS X behaviour is to delete the current line entirely, and move the cursor up one line -- such that continuously pressing the delete-all-left will continue deleting lines.

If this is intended behaviour, then it might be desirable to have a separate command, or a preference toggle, that enables the behaviour I'm describing.

data.title: Follow window.restoreWindows setting when launching Code by opening a file
data.body:
Following up on [comment thread](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/207#issuecomment-329848811) at #207.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.15063

Relevant settings:
```
"window.restoreWindows": "all",
"window.openFilesInNewWindow": "off",
"files.hotExit": "onExit"
```

1. When VS Code is already launched, open a file (from command line or Windows Explorer): file is added as an editor/tab in current workspace.
2. Launch VS Code by itself: All previously open files are restored.
3. Launch VS code by opening a file from command line or Windows Explorer: a fresh instance is created with only that file and any unsaved files; "clean" previous files/folders are not restored.

(3) is inconsistent with the expected behavior from both (1) and (2). It behaves almost as though `window.openFilesInNewWindow` is set to on when the application is closed, contra (1), and it ignores the expected behavior of the `window.restoreWindows` setting, contra (2). 

It also gives privileged status to dirty files, which are always restored, for no sensible reason -- I can easily "dirty up" saved files by making a change and immediately undoing it, and it'll be restored when launching Code by opening a file. Why not just restore all files to begin with?

Code already has the `-n` command line parameter for opening files in a new window, yet this also only works when Code is already launched. Both `-n` and `-r` behave identically (i.e., is ignored) when it is used to launch VS Code from a file, creating another inconsistency between newly launched and existing instances of Code.

Finally, it's inconsistent with session restore behavior of Notepad++ and Sublime Text. Atom behaves like Code, but even they [admit it's counter-intuitive](https://discuss.atom.io/t/why-dont-my-project-folders-stay-open-each-time-i-start-atom/31733).

Although #15949 is also open, I've created this separate issue because `code .` opens a new window even when VS Code is already launched. Hence the expected behavior already differs from (1) above.

data.title: Avoid fssync calls in workbench in extensionTipsService
data.body:
Fixes #34423

In this PR `fs.existsSync` is replaced with `pfs.fileExists`
Instead of looking at all the paths in the PATH variable we look only in the default location used for installation

data.title: Integrated terminal off-by-one rendering errors.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0 128a4e3640c5375f7b0bc1cfd37f626481b1386f
- OS Version: macOS 10.13 Beta (17A362a)


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Paste the following command into the integrated terminal:
`python -c 'print ("\x1b[31m0123456789\x1b[0m")*9`
This prints the string [RED]0123456789[RESET] nine times, followed by a newline.

2. Resize the VSCode window so that the window half clips one of the red characters, and run it again.


Issues:

The terminal output does not wrap the partially-clipped character; it is possible to resize the window so that the final character essentially disappears.

Additionally, double-clicking a line of text to select it causes the line below to become highlighted instead.

Ideally, previously rendered text would wrap dynamically as the window was resized but this is not the case.


Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Is it expected that in 1.16, Hovers with null items in their arrays do not render at all
data.body:
This seems to be a breaking change in 1.16. I don't know if it's a bug or the old behaviour is considered bad, but it's resulted in a lot of hovers no longer rendering after the update.

`HoverProvider` contains Code looks like this:

```ts
resolve(new Hover(
	[{ language: 'dart', value: data.displayString }, data.documentation],
	range
));
```

The data passed to the hover is an array - the first item is an object with a language/value and the second item is additional documentation (which is just a markdown string).

If `data.documentation` is null in 1.15, the tooltip still rendered, just ignoring the second item:

![Working hovers](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1078012/30514362-1a8b9ba2-9b0b-11e7-8601-70cf3eeb1690.png)

However after updating, the hover does not appear *at all* when there's a null in that array.

![Broken hovers](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1078012/30514368-2be2e950-9b0b-11e7-8246-5b5f50d24d8e.png)

Is this an expected change? I can update my extension not to put nulls in here, though I don't know whether this might affect other extensions too. It was kinda convenient for Code to skip over this nulls, we could just string a bunch of variables together that may or may not be set for a given hover, but now we'll need to conditionally push them onto an array before sending.

data.title: Feature Request: Navigation through Highlighted References
data.body:
In Visual Studio there are 2 keyboard shortcuts that allow you to navigate through highlighted references of the current open document.  I think it would be very useful to have these in VS Code.

For languages like c# and typescript VS Code already has the symbol information to perform the highlight, I think now it's just a matter of being able to map a key to navigate next/previous.

In Visual Studio:
Edit.NextHighlightedReference
Edit.PreviousHighlightedReference

data.body:

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- Version 1.16.1
- OS Version: Linux  4.12.13-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Sep 15 06:36:43 UTC 2017 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Build this test document in a new window(just kept ctrl+c and ctrl+v)
```
a b c 10
<Repeat last line for 999 times>
```
2. Ctrl+H to call Replacement, and input this as your regexp to replace from, and replace it to 123123:
```
^(\S+)\s+?(.+)\s+?(\d+)\d*$
```

3. Replace for all

Excepted Result:

All lines should be replaced to 123123

Produced Result:

Nothing happened.

Futher Steps:

4. Change the first line to `dddddd`

5. Replace use those arguments again

Produced Result:

All lines except the first line is replace to `123123`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Enhancement to manage extensions - bookmark, tag, metadata
data.body:
It would be useful to show bookmarks that I'm interested in (or that I'm not interested in).

Since there are so many extensions available and new ones being developed each day.    It would be nice to have a way to tag the extensions in the gallery.   The tag could be 'bookmark', 'review', 'dontuse', etc.

After some cursory review, It seems like this can be done using the galleryExtensionId.   We can store a list of the Ids and associated tags and metadata (comments, etc.) in a json file locally.

Whenever we query the extensions, we can merge the results into the UI of the Gallery or search results.

As a start, I suspect the storing of the metadata can be done with an extension itself -- would it have access to the galleryExtension id?   It probably makes more sense to integrate this into the UI of the workspace.   

I"m posting it here, because I'm interested in feedback and thoughts on this.
